channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Marine Who Urinated on Taliban Corpses Says He Has No Regrets
item.description: Staff Sgt. Joseph Chamblin said he had no regrets about the incident and would do it again out of revenge for the killing of American soldiers.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: MERS Virus Not Global Emergency, Health Officials Say
item.description: The slow spread of the illness, which has killed 45 people, mostly in the Middle East, has not prompted travel restrictions as of yet.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: The Lede: A Taliban Commander Writes to Malala Yousafzai
item.description: A senior Taliban commander blamed Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani schoolgirl shot in the head by the militant group, for provoking the attack by “smearing” the Islamists, according to a copy of a letter he wrote to her.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: 22 Children Die From Tainted Lunches at Indian School
item.description: The authorities were searching for the headmistress of a primary school in the eastern state of Bihar after children were served food contaminated with insecticide.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: A man holding the body of his daughter inside an ambulance in Patna, India, on Wednesday. Twenty-two children died after eating a free midday meal at a primary school in Bihar State.

item.title: Assad Supporter Killed by Gunmen in Southern Lebanon
item.description: Mohamed Dirrar Jammo, a prominent Syrian commentator and staunch defender of the government of President Bashar al-Assad, was gunned down Wednesday at his home.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Universities Face a Rising Barrage of Cyberattacks
item.description: The hacking attempts, many thought to be from China, are forcing universities to spend more to prevent and detect intrusions and to constrict their culture of openness.
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
item.media:description: A storage server at the University of Wisconsin.

item.title: With New Law, Afghanistan Moves Closer to an Election
item.description: Concerns that the Afghan vote set for next year might be delayed were eased when President Hamid Karzai signed a new election law.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Europe Wants More Concessions From Google
item.description: Joaquín Almunia, the European Union competition commissioner, said Google’s proposals to address antitrust concerns were “not enough.”
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Joaquín Almunia, the European Union competition commissioner, said he had asked Google "to present better proposals" to allay E.U. antitrust concerns.

item.title: Another North Korean Ship Made Cuba Run in 2012
item.description: A “mirror image” voyage that aroused no suspicion added to the intrigue around the vessel impounded by Panama for carrying concealed weapons.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Senate Panel Questions Nominee for U.N. Ambassador
item.description: Samantha Power appeared to face no serious obstacles to confirmation during a hearing of the Foreign Relations Committee.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 17
item.description: Vermicelli being dried in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A man drying strands of vermicelli in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh. It is used to make seviyan, a popular sweet dish served during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, which started on July 10.

item.title: The Lede: Prominent Gay Rights Activist Is Found Dead in Cameroon
item.description: Eric Ohena Lembembe was found dead in his home in Yaoundé, shortly after he wrote about attacks on organizations that support gay rights. Cameroon is one of 38 African countries that criminalize homosexuality.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Arab League Endorses Kerry’s Plan for Resuming Peace Talks
item.description: In a statement, Arab League diplomats in Amman, Jordan, said Secretary of State John Kerry’s ideas were a “good basis” for restarting peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Zhengzhou Journal: The Demanding Off-Hour Escapes of China’s High-Tech Workers
item.description: Young people who work making iPhones and other electronic devices in China flock to nightclubs in their time off, desperately trying to enjoy the present as they strive for a better future.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of young Chinese come to the city of Zhengzhou to work in electronics factories. To escape the monotony of the assembly line, many take up roller skating as a hobby, like at the outdoor roller rink.

item.title: Putin Does Not Expect Ties With U.S. to Be Harmed by Snowden Case
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said Wednesday that bilateral relations were more important than the controversy surrounding Edward J. Snowden, the former intelligence contractor.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:credit: Alexei Nikolsky/RIA Novosti Kremlin, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia listened to his defense minister, Sergei Shoigu, right, while observing military exercises from a helicopter on Wednesday in the Trans-Baikal region in eastern Siberia.

item.title: The Lede: Comparing Black Minister to an Orangutan Was Not Racist, Italian Senator Insists
item.description: A senior Italian senator insists that it was “an aesthetic judgment, not meant to be racist,” when he said that Italy’s first black minister looked like an ape.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Roberto Calderoli, the vice president of Italy's senate and a leader of the anti-immigrant Northern League party, at a news conference in 2011.

item.title: The Lede: New Pussy Riot Video Asks Where Russia’s Oil Wealth Goes
item.description: In a new song released online Tuesday, the Russian protest group Pussy Riot claims that billions of dollars of the nation’s oil wealth have been looted by President Vladimir V. Putin and his allies.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: A member of the Russian protest group Pussy Riot throws oil on a portrait of Alexander Bastrykin, a senior law-enforcement official, known for harassing groups critical of the president.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Literary Critic and Novelist Shamsur Rahman Faruqi
item.description: Literary critic Shamsur Rahman Faruqi speaks about his debut novel, British colonialism, and Indian history.
item.dc:creator: By SONAL SHAH
item.media:description: Shamsur Rahman Faruqi, an Urdu literary critic and author of the book "The Mirror of Beauty."

item.title: I.M.F. Tells China of Urgent Need for Economic Change
item.description: China’s domestic economic balance is precarious, the International Monetary Fund said, largely because of too little consumer spending and too much government spending.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY
item.media:description: The International Monetary Fund warned of possible sharp price drops in Chinese real estate markets. Above, a construction site in Qingdao.

item.title: Letter from India: Delhi Metro Reaches Across Class Lines
item.description: The subway system is one of the few places in India where an iPad-toting professional squeezes in next to a housemaid. It is also one of the rare government projects the public genuinely loves.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: China Detains a Leading Human Rights Advocate
item.description: Xu Zhiyong, who was held Tuesday on unlawful assembly charges, has challenged the Communist Party to act on its vows to expose corruption and respect the rule of law.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Judges of a Graceful Sport, Caught in a Clumsy Cheating Scandal
item.description: A scandal surrounding the Olympic sport of rhythmic gymnastics has implicated as many as 60 experts of the sport who were looking to qualify as official judges.
item.dc:creator: By MARY PILON
item.media:description: Rhythmic gymnastics is tangled in a scandal of judges suspected of cheating on tests.

item.title: China: Four Officials Detained Over Mine Explosions
item.description: Four local officials are being investigated for “dereliction of duty” in two coal mine blasts that killed 53 people last spring.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Guinea: Gas Station Theft Ignites Deadly Ethnic Clashes
item.description: At least 16 people have been burned alive or hacked to death with machetes, and dozens wounded, during two days of ethnic clashes in the south.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Gay Marriage Law Is Approved by Parliament
item.description: Gay marriage is to become legal in England and Wales after the lower house of Parliament approved the final changes to a law that had the backing of Prime Minister David Cameron.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
